Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research Experiences for Undergraduates in Mathematics at CSU Channel Islands
Award.AbstractNarration:
The REU in Mathematics at California State University Channel Islands will support 27 REU students conducting mathematical research in Summer 2015 and Summer 2017. Unique features include a focus on targeting talented students who might not otherwise have considered mathematics as a viable career choice, particularly those from traditionally underrepresented groups, with a special emphasis on native Spanish speakers and first-generation college students. The group of faculty mentors includes several bilingual (Spanish-English) faculty. The inclusion of one early-career mathematician from another campus each year will spread the practice of effective undergraduate research mentoring. By inviting native Spanish speakers and first-generation students to join more traditional students, this project creates a model of a diverse, rigorous research environment. Students will tackle original research problems in the areas of algebra, data analysis, graph theory, operator theory, analysis, linear algebra, applied mathematics, and their intersections that are of interest to the mathematical research community yet accessible to students.

Students will spend the bulk of their time working on research in groups of four per faculty mentor; faculty mentors will work with their students an average of 3 - 5 hours per day. Workshops, distinguished visitors and colloquia, and social outings are also included in the activities. The primary goal is for student participants to conduct original mathematical research while raising their levels of mathematical maturity and confidence and fostering an enthusiasm for mathematics. Students will develop mathematical communication skills in visual, oral, and written form. The project will incorporate students into a heterogeneous group with shared intellectual goals. Students will leave the program feeling excited and prepared to conduct graduate-level mathematics in an academic or industrial setting. We expect the emphasis on native Spanish speakers and students from underrepresented groups will broaden the pipeline into graduate school and mathematical careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CSU Channel Islands Mathematics REU engaged students intensively during the summers of 2015 and 2017, with each cohort also participating in pre-summer preparation and ongoing post-REU mentoring and professional development. Students focused on investigations of original research problems in the following eight areas. (Faculty mentors and their affiliations are listed in parentheses.)

  • Prime Numbers in Rings of Quadratic Integers (Dr. Alejandra Alvarado, Eastern Illinois University)
  • Generalized Linear Models in Social Research (Dr. Delil Martinez, CSU Channel Islands)
  • Operator Theory on Spaces Defined by Trees (Dr. Rub?n A. Mart?nez-Avenda?o, Universidad Aut?noma del
  • Estado de Hidalgo)
  • Probabilities Concerning Sets of Matrices (Dr. Brian Sittinger, CSU Channel Islands)
  • An Inverse Problem in Graph Coloring (Dr. Heather M. Russell, University of Richmond)
  • Tilings and Substitution Shifts (Dr. Benjamin Itza Ortiz, Universidad Aut?noma del
  • Estado de Hidalgo)
  • Numerical Simulation of Traffic Flow using the Viscous Burgers Equation (Dr. Cynthia Flores, CSU Channel Islands)
  • Matrix Completion Problems for Several Linear Matrix Equations (Dr. Geoffrey Buhl, CSU Channel Islands)

Activities were carefully designed to help students become independent researchers, effective members of heterogenous working groups, skilled authors and oral presenters, and to build a mutually supportive community of learners. By the end of the program, each research group prepared multiple posters and a final report detailing their results. Significant new results were obtained in seven of eight research projects; the eighth (an application) provided insight to stakeholders regarding a critical educational intervention at the host campus. Six papers have already appeared in the professional peer-reviewed journals; a seventh manuscript is in preparation for submission. Two new software products enabling further research were created and made available to the research community.

The CSU Channel Islands Mathematics REU was committed to providing enhanced access to students from underrepresented minorities and to increasing the likelihood of their retention and success in research and teaching careers. This REU was unique in its emphasis on recruiting native Spanish speakers and first-generation college students, its commitment to ensuring that at least two faculty mentor were Spanish-English bilingual each summer, and in providing all recruitment and application materials in both Spanish and English. During both 2015 and 2017, a member of the faculty of the Universidad Autonoma del Estado de Hidalgo, both Mexican nationals who live and work in Mexico, served as a research mentor and lived in residence with the students.

Students were not required to provide demographic information when they applied; the numbers in parentheses indicate the number of participants who provided data for relevant items. Amongst the participants in the 2015 and 2017 REUs were 11 (of 27) native Spanish speakers, 15 (of 33) women, 13 (of 25) students who were from groups underrepresented in the mathematical sciences, 18 (of 28) first-generation college students, and 12 (of 24) from low-income families (earning less than $40,000 annually). In addition to the publication results cited above, all students presented their final results in at least one national conference. Most of the students have entered graduate programs in the mathematical sciences: this is particularly noteworthy as many students selected for the program were either not intending to pursue graduate study or noncommittal regarding pursuing graduate study.

The CSU Channel Islands Mathematics REU also enhanced human capacity through deliberately inviting less experienced faculty mentors to participate and then providing a professional development program for all faculty mentors. Each year's faculty mentors and the directors communicated extensively prior to the start of the REU and met formally weekly and informally almost daily throughout the REU with the explicit goal of learning from one another about how best to mentor heterogeneous groups of undergraduates in research activities. Other topics included best practices for writing grants, particularly in teams. REU visitors often engaged in informal faculty mentoring conversations. This practice of faculty mentoring enabled the REU to engage a mentor and director group of size 10 that included 6 women and 5 native Spanish speakers, further demonstrating to the student participants that mathematics can be an inclusive discipline in which anyone can succeed.
